dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, she was a hundred and one, and just passed away in Pavlodar. It's really sobering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, she was a hundred and one, and just passed away in Pavlodar. It's really sobering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Maria Kurbatova, a veteran sniper of the Great Patriotic War and participant in the liberation of Ukraine, Poland, and Czechoslovakia, has passed away in Pavlodar at the age of 101, her family confirmed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And she wasn't just any soldier—she was a trained sniper, you know? Volunteered at nineteen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And she wasn't just any soldier-she was a trained sniper, you know? Volunteered at nineteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1943, at the age of 19, she volunteered for the front. After training at a sniper school near Moscow, she joined the 650th Rifle Regiment of the 138th Rifle Division, which had been awarded the Order of Suvorov.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, after starting in an evacuation hospital. Then she went to sniper school near Moscow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, after starting in an evacuation hospital. Then she went to sniper school near Moscow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kurbatova began her wartime service in an evacuation hospital, caring for the wounded. In 1943, at the age of 19, she volunteered for the front. After training at a sniper school near Moscow, she joined the 650th Rifle Regiment of the 138th Rifle Division, which had been awarded the Order of Suvorov.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Can you imagine? Joining the 650th Rifle Regiment, fighting all across Eastern Europe…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Can you imagine? Joining the six hundred fiftieth Rifle Regiment, fighting all across Eastern Europe...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After training at a sniper school near Moscow, she joined the 650th Rifle Regiment of the 138th Rifle Division, which had been awarded the Order of Suvorov.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Ukraine, Poland, Czechoslovakia… She earned so many honors. The Order of Zhukov, For Courage…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ukraine, Poland, Czechoslovakia... She earned so many honors. The Order of Zhukov, For Courage...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a senior sergeant, Kurbatova fought in campaigns to liberate Ukraine, Poland, and Czechoslovakia. She returned home with numerous military honors, including the Orders of the Patriotic War and Zhukov, as well as the medals For Courage, For Military Merit, and For the Victory over Germany.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And after everything, she came home and taught military training, became an accountant. Just incredible resilience.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And after everything, she came home and taught military training, became an accountant. Just incredible resilience.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After the war, she taught basic military training, became a certified accountant, married, and raised a family.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Her family said she never complained. Always that enduring smile, even when reporters visited her right before Victory Day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Her family said she never complained. Always that enduring smile, even when reporters visited her right before Victory Day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This year, just days before Victory Day, our reporters visited her at home, where she welcomed guests with the same kind and enduring smile she had carried throughout her life. Her loved ones remember her as a warm and optimistic person who never complained and always wished for peace.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: In her last interview, she said she just wanted children to play in peace, no more war. That really gets me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: In her last interview, she said she just wanted children to play in peace, no more war. That really gets me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I really, really want there to be no more war. I want children to play in parks and gardens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Me too. And now there are only seven WWII veterans left in Pavlodar region. We're losing them so fast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me too. And now there are only seven W W I I veterans left in Pavlodar region. We're losing them so fast.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until recently, Maria Kurbatova was the oldest living veteran in the Pavlodar region. Only seven WWII veterans now remain in the area.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Valentina Volkodav also just passed at a hundred and three up in Petropavlovsk. It's… it's a lot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Valentina Volkodav also just passed at a hundred and three up in Petropavlovsk. It's... it's a lot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 103-year-old WWII veteran Valentina Volkodav passed away in Petropavlovsk

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: These were the people who lived through hell and still wished nothing but peace for the next generation. We can't forget that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: These were the people who lived through hell and still wished nothing but peace for the next generation. We can't forget that.
